results.headline: Damaged Souls Looking to Sail Away

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Drunkboat

results.summary_short: In “Drunkboat” John Malkovich plays an alcoholic former poet looking to escape from a Chicago suburb.

results.headline: An Artist and Inventor Whose Medium Was Sound
results.display_title: Deconstructing Dad: The Music, Machines, and Mystery Of Raymond Scott

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Deconstructing Dad: The Music, Machines, and Mystery Of Raymond Scott

results.summary_short: In “Deconstructing Dad,” Stan Warnow tries to understand his elusive father, the musical inventor Raymond Scott.

results.headline: Beyond Word Games, Puzzles About Reality

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Alps

results.summary_short: A mysterious quartet impersonates the dead to help, somehow, the bereaved in the Greek film “Alps.”

results.headline: Juggling Drugs, Thugs and Privilege in Sweden

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Easy Money

results.summary_short: Adapted from a crime novel by Jens Lapidus, “Easy Money” tells a tale of cocaine, gangsters and the upper class in Stockholm.

results.headline: Two Victims of a Serial Rapist Share an Enduring Trauma

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Invisible

results.summary_short: Two rape victims connect decades after their attacks, bonding while coming to grips with the trauma and how their lives have evolved, in Michal Aviad’s “Invisible.”

results.headline: Too Old for Sibling Rivalry? Never, Brothers Say

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Do-Deca Pentathlon

results.summary_short: In “The Do-Deca-Pentathlon,” two brothers take up an unfinished competition from high school and exhibit a primal male rivalry whose force outweighs reason and common sense.

results.headline: Young Dreamers Tangled in Reality

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Starry Starry Night

results.summary_short: In “Starry Starry Night,” the director Tom Shu-Yu Lin creates a fantasy world for a 13-year-old girl struggling to deal with her grandfather’s death.

results.headline: Stone and His Stoners Face the Weed Killers

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Savages

results.summary_short: “Savages,” Oliver Stone’s feverish adaptation of Don Winslow’s drug-war novel, is a pulpy daylight noir, a western, a stoner buddy movie and a love story.

results.headline: Look Homeward, Evil: Sinister Family Secrets

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Pact

results.summary_short: Returning home after her mother dies has creepy consequences for a woman in “The Pact,” a horror movie that explores the haunted-house genre.

results.headline: Not Quite Innisfree, but Still an Island That Delivers Peace

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Magic Of Belle Isle

results.summary_short: “The Magic of Belle Isle,” directed by Rob Reiner, stars Morgan Freeman as a drunken, once-celebrated writer whose move to a summer lakeside cabin gives him a new perspective on life.

results.headline: Traveling With Dad to Hearts Unknown

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Last Ride

results.summary_short: “Last Ride,” an Australian film, stars Hugo Weaving as a man on the run and on the road with his 10-year-old son.

results.headline: Telling a Cautionary Tale, Happy Ending Optional

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Crazy Eyes

results.summary_short: “Crazy Eyes,” a film by Adam Sherman, follows a rich, divorced Los Angeles man trying to navigate a life filled with booze and women.

results.headline: One Gun, Two Men and Tense Conversation

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Collaborator

results.summary_short: In Martin Donovan’s hostage drama, “Collaborator,” a mentally disturbed neighbor holds a childhood acquaintance captive.

results.headline: Fragile Yet Hard-Fought Hopes of Better Lives

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of China Heavyweight

results.summary_short: “China Heavyweight,” a documentary by Yung Chang, follows two boys from Sichuan Province as they face the demands of the Chinese amateur boxing program.

results.headline: A Pop Sweetie With Edge

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Katy Perry: Part of Me

results.summary_short: “Katy Perry: Part of Me” documents the 2011 concert tour of that pop singer, who is an energetic, industrious personification of the paradoxes that contemporary commercial music encompasses.

results.headline: A Teenage Transformation Like No Other

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Amazing Spider-Man

results.summary_short: “The Amazing Spider-Man” is a resuscitated studio product held aloft by its stars, Andrew Garfield and Emma Stone.

results.headline: One Woman No One Wants to Tangle With

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tyler Perry's Madea's Witness Protection

results.summary_short: Tyler Perry is back with Madea, a little less sassy in this film, as she shelters a witness in a Ponzi scheme.

results.headline: Sometimes Attraction Becomes a Slow Dance Around the Subject

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Take this Waltz

results.summary_short: “Take This Waltz,” written and directed by Sarah Polley, follows a married woman and single man as they navigate their attraction.

results.headline: The Body Politic

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Magic Mike

results.summary_short: Channing Tatum stars in “Magic Mike,” Steven Soderbergh’s funny, enjoyable romp about male strippers and the American dream.

results.headline: Old Man of Rock Takes a Road Trip

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Neil Young Journeys

results.summary_short: In Jonathan Demme’s new documentary, “Neil Young Journeys,” the roar is more earthshaking than earsplitting.
